image.caption: Collection of the U.S. House of Representatives

profileText: A Representative from Connecticut; born Barbara Ann Bailey, in Hartford, Conn., July 10, 1936; attended St. Joseph Cathedral School; graduated from Mount St. Joseph Academy, West Hartford, 1954; B.A., Trinity College, Washington, D.C., 1958; certificate in business administration, Harvard Business School, 1959; M.A., Trinity College, Hartford, Conn., 1971; member, Hartford Court of Common Council, 1975-1979; secretary of state of Connecticut, 1979-1982; elected as a Democrat to the Ninety-seventh Congress, by special election, to fill the vacancy caused by the death of United States Representative William R. Cotter, and reelected to the eight succeeding Congresses (January 12, 1982-January 3, 1999); was not a candidate in 1998 for reelection to the U.S. House of Representatives but was an unsuccessful candidate for Governor of Connecticut.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: "Barbara B. Kennelly" in Women in Congress, 1917-2006. Prepared under the direction of the Committee on House Administration by the Office of History & Preservation, U.S. House of Representatives. Washington: Government Printing Office, 2006.

researchRecord.name: 1982-1990; 4 commercials on 3 videoreels, 12 commercials on 6 videocassettes, and 2 commercials on 2 sound tape reels.
researchRecord.description: The commercials used during Barbara Kennelly's campaigns for the 1982, 1984, 1986, 1988, and 1990 U.S. congressional elections in District 1, Connecticut, Democratic Party.

recordLocation.name: The Julian P. Kanter Political Commercial Archive, Department of Communication

researchRecord.name: In the Estonian, Latvian, Lithuanian Alliance Of Connecticut (ELLA) Records, 1938-1996, 1.75 linear feet.
In the Foster Gunnison, Jr. Papers, ca. 1945-1994, 55 linear feet.
ca. 1977-1998, 79.3 linear feet.
researchRecord.description: The collection of Barbara Kennelly includes correspondence to and from constituents and colleagues, notes, research materials, speeches, official congressional documents, congressional records, press clips, photographs, audio and video tapes, and special interest reports. A finding aid is available in the repository and online: http://www.lib.uconn.edu/online/research/speclib/ASC/findaids/Kennelly/MSS19980369.html.
